ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: Instructor: Lan Jin  Jin
Instructor: Lan Jin  Lan Jin
Instructor: Lan Jin  Jin, Lan
Instructor: Lan Jin  Jin, Lan

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Nothing toshow..

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I think the online lectures were helpful and gave a strong overview of ethical considerations from a variety of perspectives. I do think in order for the class to feel a bit more substantive the in-class lecture time should be extended to 90 minutes rather than 1 hour.

I am highly critical of this course. This is for two reasons: (1) I think environmental ethics is super important and needs greater emphasis here at FES, (2) this course is a huge missed opportunity in supporting learning around environmental ethics at FES.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The material. Normally I don't like online video lectures, but these interviews were really interesting to watch. And Michelle Bell was awesome! I really liked her a lot and hope I can take another class with her next year. I really appreciate how she incorporated issues that are not always present elsewhere (environmental justice, environmental health, etc.)
Interviews with experts were really engaging - it would be great to have them guest lecture some time in the future.

The subject matter is vital for people to learn, at least since the concepts behind thought experiments are broadly applicable in post-grad life, even if the thought experiments themselves will never actually happen.
Not to be flippant, but there weren't any that I can recall.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: So I think this class is really important and I'm SO glad it's at FES. But this format doesn't do the material justice. We would have really benefitted from a longer class time for more discussion - things always felt very rushed. I like the half-semester schedule, but maybe a 1.5-2 hour meeting slot instead of just 1 hour?
Time could be extended for class discussion. Sometimes felt like the class wasnt as focused as it could have been.

The course readings and work were not taught in a very engaging manner. Professor Bell explained topics well and was responsive to questions, but the layout of the course really felt shallow in how topics were discussed. Things seemed glossed over. I think the flipped nature of the class hurts it in some ways, and stronger lecture times would be better.

I think this course should be expanded for more credits and to provide more time for classroom lecture and discussion. I would have definitely liked to have more in-class time to hear other students thoughts and get more lecture from Professor Bell.

This course needs an overhaul. The weeks did not seem to build on one another. The readings were too broad. The online discussion forum was not particularly useful or illuminating. In-class presentations were not an effective way to learn.
Explanation of jow the group "debates" would be performed/function.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: Difficult to tie class discussion to lectures as it felt difficult to develop dialogue in the class particularly within the time frame allotted.
N/A
Excellent

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I was excited to learn more about environmental ethics and philosophy. I gained very little from this course. This is not a 2-credit course. It is hardly a 1-credit course, to be honest.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I think it's important, I wanted to take a class with Michelle, and it was really great from a scheduling perspective.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Not exactly, but I think that's a function of it being a 2 credit/half semester class. I do know more than I did before!

No. I learned very little from this course. The readings, lectures (they were very few), and the class projects all felt very disconnected. Students were unsure what the overall goals of the course were and what the lessons for each week were.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It provided a chance to extend discussion about ethics outside the classroom and class time, and into the group work. I appreciated how low key the group projects were.
There was a wide range of disciplines in the class which was great as I don't get to engage with many of my peers from other FES programs or focus areas.
The group work was poor quality and largely a waste of time.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Michelle is great!! And its a wonderful class for a 2-credit course.
Save the lecture videos and take notes as they are really fantastic!

In its current form, this is not a particularly useful or interesting course. I would recommend looking at the syllabus and talking with students who have taken the course. This course needs help. This is true for many of the 6-week courses. It is hard to gain much from 6 short weeks. If you are someone who wants a super easy 2-credits and wants to simply watch some videos on-line this may be a good class for you. But if you want your time at Yale to be a bit more meaningful, find another class. I would suggest looking at some courses at the Divinity School instead. Look at classes by Willie Jennings. He seems good.

This is a interesting course, but it could benefit from a longer and more vigourous course structure. I really enjoyed the in-class discussions and thought all the material was very valid and interesting. I just wish there was more time to get into the topics in a little more depth.
